event_registry_properties.name: title
event_registry_properties.item: Sun Crypto Accelerator 4000 Firmware May Be Defective
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: The Solaris Fault Manager has determined that a firmware defect was detected on Sun Crypto Accelerator 4000 card which requires repair action.
event_registry_properties.name: response
event_registry_properties.item: The driver has been disabled and unregistered as a hardware provider to the Solaris Cryptographic Framework.
event_registry_properties.name: impact
event_registry_properties.item: The card will no longer function as a network device or cryptographic accelerator until the problem has been resolved.
event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item:
Run pkgchk -n SUNWvcafw to ensure that the latest firmware package is correctly installed and has been downloaded to the adapter (rsrc) identified in the fmdump(1M) output as instructed in the Sun Crypto Accelerator 4000 Board Installation and Users Guide.

If the latest firmware has already been correctly installed, contact Sun for support.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
The Message ID:  %MSGID% indicates diagnosis has determined that the firmware running on the SCA4000 PCI adapter is defective. The SCA4000 (vca) driver has disabled the network and cryptographic accelerator interfaces. Insure that the latest firmware package (SUNWvcafw) is installed on the system and that the firmware supplied with that package (sca4000fw) has been downloaded to the card before contacting Sun for support. The version 2.0 driver will only work with firmware version 2.0 or higher.

Refer to the Sun Crypto Accelerator 4000 Board Installation and Users Guide for information on determining version of firmware currently running on the card and downloading the correct version if necessary.

After installing the latest firmware version, the network and cryptographic accelerator interfaces may be brought back into service using the fmadm(1M) command:

fmadm repair <EVENT-ID>
